issue.title: Inline "conditional" @var annoation gets ignored

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

body:
> No matter where you put `/** @var array<int, array{string, int}> $matches */`, `$matches` remains typed as `array<array-key, string>`.

That's down to how it's defined in the callmap, I believe.
I think the idea of parameter-mapped types definition has been discussed elsewhere- @muglug, is there a way around this that doesn't require implementing parameter-mapped types ?

issue.title: Can't delcare variable type by comment

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
This example shouldn't show error: https://psalm.dev/r/f7478fba75
Psalm should respect variable declaration via @var tag.

body:
For the few cases where this is needed a possible workaround is to put a semicolon after the doc comment, then it's taken into account: https://psalm.dev/r/29441019f5

PHP seems to [ignore empty statements](https://3v4l.org/W5ZNb/vld#output) so doing this should be ok (although some CS tools might complain).

issue.title: Cannot override variable type with phpdoc

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
https://psalm.dev/r/0f31b34d81

Expected: no issues
Actual: UndefinedInterfaceMethod - 16:23 - Method BaseInterface::getsome does not exist

body:
@muglug Do you have some hint to share on this? Where should I look to begin? 

I suppose #1111 can be handled at the same time

I see some statements that could benefit from this:
- assignations
- global keyword use (#1111)
- condition or loop with assignations inside (while, if, ...)
Do you see some other cases?
@orklah the `StatementsAnalyzer` has parsing for var docblocks already  I think you'd just want to assign the variables right there, except for `foreach`, `return` and `assign` statements

issue.title: Not possible to set @var after initialization

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.body:
It's not possible to set @var after initialization.

In our project, we have code that can be simplified down to https://psalm.dev/r/a7893997f9. (ofc not random_int(0,1), but a $node can be Project or Task, checked by `if(in_array($node->getType(), ['Project', 'Task'])) && ($topProject = $node->GetRootProject())) {`)

Is there any possibility that this can be supported? If not, I will have to find another way of doing this.

issue.title: Inline declaration of global variable

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

issue.title: Inline declaration of variable type

repository.name: psalm
repository.description: A PHP static analysis tool for finding errors and security vulnerabilities in PHP applications

body:
I found these snippets:
<details>
<summary>https://psalm.dev/r/d1eac9433a</summary>

```php
<?php
$text = '
foobar
foobaz
fooqux
foobop
';

preg_match_all("/(?'word'foob[\w]*)/", $text, $matches);

/**
 * @var array{
 *     word: string[]
 * } $params
 */
$params = $matches;

for ($i = 0; $i < count($params['word']); $i++) {
    echo $params['word'][$i] . "\n";
}
```

```
Psalm output (using commit 931d35a):

No issues!
```
</details>
